ai-dn2:0.3_0: 1. A Discussion With the King’s Ministers
ai-dn2:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha in the Mango Grove of Jīvaka Komārabhacca, together with a large Saṅgha of 1,250 mendicants.
ai-dn2:1.3_0: Now, at that time it was the sabbath—the Komudi full moon on the fifteenth day of the fourth month—and King Ajātasattu Vedehiputta of Magadha was sitting upstairs in the royal longhouse surrounded by his ministers.
ai-dn2:1.4_0: Then Ajātasattu expressed this heartfelt sentiment,
ai-dn2:1.5_0: “Oh, sirs, this moonlit night is so very delightful, so beautiful, so glorious, so lovely, so striking.
ai-dn2:1.6_0: What ascetic or brahmin might we pay homage to today?”
ai-dn2:2.1_0: When he had spoken, one of the king’s ministers said to him,
ai-dn2:2.2_0: “Sire, Pūraṇa Kassapa leads an order and a community, and teaches a community. He’s a well-known and famous religious founder, regarded as holy by many people. He is of long standing, long gone forth; he is advanced in years and has reached the final stage of life.
ai-dn2:2.3_0: Let Your Majesty pay homage to him.
ai-dn2:2.4_0: Hopefully in so doing your mind will find peace.”
ai-dn2:2.5_0: When he said this, King Ajātasattu kept silent.

ai-dn2:11.1_0: Then King Ajātasattu rode on the elephant as far as the terrain allowed, then descended and approached the pavilion door on foot,
ai-dn2:11.1_1: Then he went to Jīvaka and said to him,
ai-dn2:11.2_0: “But my dear Jīvaka, where is the Buddha?”
ai-dn2:11.3_0: “That is the Buddha, great king, that is the Buddha!
ai-dn2:11.4_0: He’s sitting against the central column facing east, in front of the Saṅgha of mendicants.”
ai-dn2:12.1_0: Then the king went up to the Buddha.
ai-dn2:12.2_0: He looked around the Saṅgha of monks, who were so very silent, like a still, clear lake, and expressed this heartfelt sentiment,
ai-dn2:12.3_0: “May he be blessed with such peace as the Saṅgha of mendicants now enjoys!”
ai-dn2:12.4_0: “Has your mind gone to one you love, great king?”
ai-dn2:12.5_0: “I love my son, sir, Prince Udāyibhadda.
ai-dn2:12.6_0: May he be blessed with such peace as the Saṅgha of mendicants now enjoys!”
ai-dn2:13.1_0: Then the king bowed to the Buddha, raised his joined palms toward the Saṅgha, and sat down to one side.
ai-dn2:13.3_0: “Sir, I’d like to ask you about a certain point, if you’d take the time to answer.”
ai-dn2:13.4_0: If the Buddha answers me, I’ll answer.”
ai-dn2:14.1_0: “Sir, there are many different professional fields.

ai-dn2:14.3_0: They also include bakers, barbers, bathroom attendants, cooks, garland-makers, dyers, weavers, basket-makers, potters, accountants, finger-talliers, or those following any similar professions. All these live off the fruits of their profession which are apparent in the present life.
ai-dn2:14.4_0: They pass away from that host of happiness. They nurture happiness and are conducive to heaven, ripening in happiness and leading to heaven. And they establish an uplifting religious donation for ascetics and brahmins that’s conducive to heaven.
ai-dn2:14.5_0: Sir, can you point out a fruit of the ascetic life that’s likewise apparent in the present life?”

ai-dn2:15.3_0: “If you wouldn’t mind, great king, tell me how they answered.”
